Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story: This morning, I stared at my wallet, feeling the weight of two promises. My son’s eyes had sparkled for weeks, counting down to the day I’d buy him the Nintendo I’d promised. He’d done his chores, saved his allowance, and I’d told him I’d cover the rest. But as I checked my bank balance, I felt a knot in my stomach—money was tight, and I needed to be careful to keep us afloat. At the same time, today was voting day. I’d set aside my afternoon to go to the polls, and I knew I needed to bring valid ID. I had my driver’s license, but my passport and other cards were at home. If I forgot them, I could come back later, but that would mean more time away from work—and from my son, who was waiting for his reward. I felt torn, pulled between being the reliable parent who keeps promises and the responsible citizen who makes time to vote. My mind raced, trying to figure out how to do both, knowing that something had to give.
